questions.text: Which of the following characteristic features would you expect to see in a histopathology slide of conjunctiva?

choices.text: Amacrine cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Goblet cells within non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Goblet cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
Amacrine cells within keratinized stratified squamous epithelium

questions.solution:
The presence of goblet cells within the non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium would help identify the conjunctiva. Goblet cells are involved in the secretion of mucin.

Amacrine cells are a type of retinal interneuron, and hence would be found in the retina, not the conjunctiva.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Moraxella species, a type of gram-negative diplobacilli, are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis which is a type of chronic conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis where there is inflammation of the conjunctiva at the lid margins and the inner and outer canthi of the eyes with red, scaly, excoriated, macerated and fissured skin at the canthi. This is because of the proteolytic enzymes secreted by the Moraxella species.

Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. These patients can also have associated blepharitis and papillary and follicular conjunctivitis.

Causative organisms are Moraxella lacunata, Moraxella axenfeld and Staphylococcus aureus (Rare cause). The source of infection is typically the nasal tract or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs. Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide as it inhibits proteolytic enzymes.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient infected with angular conjunctivitis.

Other options: 

Option B: Haemophilus influenzae causes acute conjunctivitis.

Option C: Adenovirus is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis and it most commonly causes follicular conjunctivitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

Option D: Coxsackie B virus is known to cause aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, pericarditis, and myocarditis. There are no known mentions of ocular disease caused by the virus.

Note: Pathogens that cause bacterial conjunctivitis

Hyperacute (symptoms develop within 24 hours; aggressive course) Acute (resolving in less than 4 weeks)  Chronic (of greater than 4 weeks duration)
Neisseria gonorrhoeae Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus
Neisseria meningitidis Streptococcus pneumoniae Moraxella lacunata
  Haemophilus influenzae Enteric bacteria

The below-given table elaborates on the type of conjunctivitis caused by different serotypes of adenovirus.

Conjunctivitis type Adenovirus serotype

Follicular Conjunctivitis

Adenovirus serotypes 1-11 and 19

Pharyngoconjunctival Fever

Adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, and 7

Epidemic Keratoconjunctivitis

Adenovirus serotypes 8, 19, and 37

questions.text: A child presents with irritation and redness of the left eye at a primary health center. There are no previous immunization records. Examination showed a greyish-white membrane over the bulbar and palpebral conjunctiva which bled on peeling. What is the likely etiology?
questions.solution:
The of a child with irritation and redness of the eye with no previous vaccination records is suggestive of a case of membranous conjunctivitis and among the given options, Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the most likely etiological agent.

Membranous conjunctivitis presents with irritation and redness of the eye and is characterized by the formation of a greyish-white membrane that bleeds on peeling. Vaccines are routinely used to prevent diphtheria infection and hence, unvaccinated status increases his susceptibility to the bacteria. Moreover, the bacteria thrive in crowded populations and poor hygienic surroundings, hence a background of low socioeconomic context, such as an orphanage, acts as a risk factor in this case.

This condition is associated with the formation of fibrinous exudates on the surface and into the substance of the conjunctival epithelium. The causes include beta-hemolytic streptococci, Streptococcus pneumonia, Haemophilus aegyptius, Corynebacterium diphtheria, and Neisseria gonorrhea

The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pseudomembranous conjunctivitis. It differs from membranous conjunctivitis in that the membrane can be easily peeled off in this condition leaving an intact underlying epithelium.

questions.text: A child with pharyngitis, and fever subsequently develops conjunctivitis. Initially, the left eye was affected, followed by the right eye's involvement in 2 days. Epiphora, conjunctival hyperemia, and chemosis are noted.  What is its most likely etiological agent?
questions.solution:
This child with pharyngitis and subsequent involvement of the eyes most likely has pharyngoconjunctival fever. This condition is commonly caused by adenovirus serotypes 3, 4, and 7. 

Pharyngoconjunctival fever is an acute and highly infectious illness characterized by fever, pharyngitis, acute follicular conjunctivitis, and regional lymphoid hyperplasia with tender, enlarged preauricular adenopathy. Within the classical triad, symptoms may vary in severity. It is usually bilateral, with one eye typically having onset 1-3 days prior to the second eye. It is a self-limiting disease and treatment is mainly symptomatic, as follows:

  • Cold compresses several times per day for 1-2 weeks.
  • Artificial tears 4-8 times per day for 1-3 weeks.

Newcastle conjunctivitis is usually clinically indistinguishable from this condition and is derived from contact with diseased fowls. Another conjunctivitis caused by adenovirus serotypes 8, 19  and 37 is known as epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient with pharyngoconjunctival fever. Significant conjunctival hyperemia, petechial subconjunctival hemorrhages, and conjunctival follicles are noted.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: The condition is commonly associated with a benign course.
It can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension.
The blood gets absorbed gradually in 6-8 weeks time without treatment.
Use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.solution:
The image given above shows a subconjunctival haemorrhage in the eye. In this condition, the blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks time without treatment.

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with systolic hypertension or after local trauma. The condition is commonly associated with a benign course but, if the posterior limit of the hemorrhage is not seen, one should check for the base of the skull fracture. 

Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukaemia. The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

questions.text: A UNICEF volunteer presented with a bilateral red eye of 2 days duration beginning on a return flight from Ghana. The infection spread among all her family members within a day of her return. Initial examination revealed lid edema, serous discharge, and severe sub-conjunctival hemorrhage. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with bilateral red-eye and a rapid spread of infection to family members points towards a likely diagnosis of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. Examination findings of lid edema, serous discharge, and subconjunctival hemorrhage further consolidate this diagnosis.

Causes:

  • Enterovirus 70 (most important)
  • Coxsackievirus 24
  • Echovirus 34
  • Adenovirus
  • Pneumococcus
  • Haemophilus

There is no treatment currently available. The infection generally resolves itself within a five to seven-day period. The use of steroids can actually cause a corneal microbial superinfection which then requires antimicrobial therapy to eliminate.

The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

Note: Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis was first recognized as a clinical entity in Ghana in 1969 when a worldwide pandemic ensued due to the infection from enterovirus 70.

questions.text: What is the cause of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornoviruses namely enterovirus 70.

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis also known as "Apollo conjunctivitis" is caused by picornoviruses such as enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus A24. Rarely it is also caused by adenovirus type 11.

It manifests with severe conjunctival congestion, chemosis, subconjunctival hemorrhages, painful follicular conjunctivitis, tearing, lid edema and pre-auricular lymphadenopathy. The cornea may demonstrate a fine punctate keratopathy. The disease is usually self-limiting, running a course of 3-7 days.

The image given below shows the eyes of a patient with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. 

Enterovirus 71 (Option D) is associated with fatal meningitis, encephalitis, and paralysis. It is also implicated in Hand-Foot-Mouth disease(HFMD) and Herpangia which is papulo-vesiculo-ulcerative rash in oral cavity.

questions.text: A tribal farmer, presented with a three-day history of right eye redness with pain. He had spent the prior week trekking up a mountain in order to travel to the nearby town and takes such trips frequently. The following lesion was observed on examination. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of right eye redness with pain, and findings of a raised whitish-yellowish lesion surrounded by mild erythema, points toward a likely diagnosis of pinguecula. A history of trekking, along with chronic sunlight exposure as a farmer, acts as a risk factor because it increases the exposure to the stronger UV radiation in the mountains.

Pinguecula has a fatty appearance and is usually bilateral. They are more often located nasally than temporally. It has horizontally oriented areas of bulbar conjunctival thickening that adjoin the limbus in the palpebral fissure area. They are associated with a 2- to 3-fold increased incidence of age-related macular degeneration. It is seen in most eyes by 70 years of age and in almost all by 80 years of age.

Pingueculitis responds to a brief course of NSAIDs or topical corticosteroids. Simple excision may be warranted in rare cases, wherein pingueculae may be chronically inflamed or cosmetically unsatisfactory.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium. 

Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue and is never inflammatory. It occurs due to exposure to UV-B radiation and the most common site is the nasal.

It is made up of three parts, "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head, and a body.

Clinical features:

  • Astigmatism with the rule - most common finding
  • Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge
  • Fuchs islets - small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge.

The differential diagnosis is pseudo pterygium. 

Pterygium Pseudo-pterygium
Degenerative process Inflammatory process
Occurs in elderly  Can occur at any age
Situated at the palpebral aperture Can occur at any site
Either progressive, regressive, or stationary Always stationary
A probe cannot be passed underneath A probe can be passed under the neck

The treatment for pterygium is usually excision. To prevent a recurrence, mitomycin C or 5 fluorouracil is used. Other methods:

  • Auto-grafting- Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method.
  • Bare sclera technique- high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%.
  • PERFECT surgery- zero rates of recurrence. (PERFECT stands for Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant)

questions.text: The excision of a pinkish, triangular tissue growth at the 1 o’clock position of the eye is being performed. The patient had a history of blurry vision and persistent redness in both eyes for a month. In order to secure the graft in the scleral bed, which of the following will not be used?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette, with symptoms of blurry vision and persistent redness, along with findings of an abnormal triangular mass of thickened conjunctiva, is suggestive of pterygium. Cyanoacrylate is not used for pterygium surgery.

The various glues used in ophthalmology are as follows:

  • Cyanoacrylate glue- Mainly used as a corneal patch to seal acute corneal perforations and improve visual outcomes, with reduced enucleation rates and need for tectonic keratoplasty
  • Fibrin glue- It is a biological adhesive, which reduces the total surgical time. It is used in corneal and conjunctival surgeries, squint surgeries, cataract (to fix the haptics of intraocular lens [IOL] to the tissue in place of sutures in glued IOL), refractive surgeries, trabeculectomy, and even retinal surgeries.
  • Newer tissue adhesives like bio-dendrimers and photo-cross-linkable adhesives-
    1. Bovine serum albumin-based bioadhesives: used in squint surgery
    2. Riboflavin-based bioadhesive activated on exposure to ultraviolet A: used in post-LASIK ectasia, infectious keratopathy, pseudophakic bullous keratopathy
    3. Hyaluronic acid-based photocatalytic glue activated with argon LASER: used in the repair of corneal lacerations

questions.text: A man presented with red eyes associated with a sandy, gritty sensation. He was diagnosed with conjunctivitis last week, however, his symptoms persisted. He has had multiple sexual partners in the past. Examination revealed palpable preauricular nodes and a follicular reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds. Conjunctival scrapings were sent for culture. What is the likely organism involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of red eyes, along with the examination findings of palpable preauricular nodes and follicular reaction involving the bulbar conjunctiva and semilunar folds, is suggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis. It is also known as chlamydial conjunctivitis, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D–K. It is a sexually transmitted disease occurring commonly in young adults.

The modes of transmission include orogenital activities and hand-to-eye spread of infective genital secretions. Hence, it is important to treat all sexual partners simultaneously to prevent re-infection and to rule out other venereal diseases, such as gonorrhoea and syphilis. Treatment includes a single 1g dose of azithromycin or doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 7 days.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient with chlamydial conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is closely related to mucus fishing syndrome?
questions.solution:
Mucus fishing syndrome is closely related to giant papillary conjunctivitis.

In Mucus fishing syndrome, patients develop a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus. The severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis is known as giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC). It is most frequently encountered with contact lens (CL) wear; in such cases, it is termed contact lens-associated papillary conjunctivitis (CLPC). 

The increased risk in contact lens users is because of the build-up of proteinaceous deposits and cellular debris on the contact lens surface. It may be also be caused by ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles, corneal surface irregularity, or filtering blebs.

questions.text: A young man presented with watering, redness and photophobia. He had similar complaints in the past which improved with self-medicated topical drops. His best-corrected visual acuity is 6/36 improving to 6/24. Slit-lamp examination revealed a 3 mm × 2 mm epithelial defect in the paracentral part of the cornea that stained positive with fluorescein dyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of spring catarrh. Slit-lamp examination finding of shield ulcer is typical of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or warm weather conjunctivitis (another name of VKC).

Shield ulcers are transverse ulcers seen in the upper cornea due to epithelial macroerosions in VKC. It is a rare complication of VKC and should always be kept in mind for patients suffering from vernal conjunctivitis.

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon- resembles arcus senilus; has a cupid's bow outline

Treatment of VKC is mainly with allergy avoidance and lid hygiene. Cool compresses, topical antihistamines, topical NSAIDs and topical steroids can be used to reduce the intensity of symptoms. 

The image given below shows a shield ulcer in a patient with VKC.

questions.text: While browsing through the news channels, Geeta came across a panel discussion on public health diseases celebrating the elimination of a peculiar condition of the eye. It was known as the most important cause of corneal blindness in India and shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given sago-grain appearance of the conjunctiva is seen in trachoma. It was the most important cause of corneal blindness in India affecting young children. 

Conjunctival appearance:

1. In trachoma

  • Sago-grain appearance
  • A follicular reaction 

2. In vernal keratoconjunctivitis

  • Cobblestone appearance
  • A papillary reaction seen in palpebral conjunctiva

3. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis

  • White-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva

4. Xerophthalmia

  • Epithelial xerosis
  • Bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva

On December 08, 2017, Shri J P Nadda, Union Minister of Health and Family Welfare at that time, released the National Trachoma Survey Report and declared that India is now free from 'infective trachoma'.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be seen as a corneal sign in a 6-year-old patient with trachoma?
questions.solution:
Arlt’s line is a conjunctival sign of trachoma. 

Corneal signs Conjunctival signs
  • Superficial keratitis
  • Follicles in the limbal area
  • Pannus- superior limbus
  • Corneal ulcer
  • Herberts pits- near Limbal area
  • Corneal opacity
  • Congestion- On upper tarsal, fornix
  • Follicles (containing Leber cells on histopathology)- On upper tarsal, fornix
  • Papillary hyperplasia
  • Arlt’s line- Linear scarring in sulcus subtarsalis
  • Concretions- Inspissated mucus, dead epithelial cells in the glands of Henle

questions.text: A young girl has been brought in by her grandmother because she has constant pain, photosensitivity and discharge from her eyes. From the notes, you see that the child has had multiple presentations for prior eye infections. You observe severe scarring on the palpebral conjunctiva, as well as trachomatous trichiasis. Which McCallan stage will this be classified under?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a young child with pain, photosensitivity and discharge, having repeated infections, along with findings of scarring and trichiasis is suggestive of trachoma. Cicatrising trachoma is stage 3 of trachoma and is characterized by scarring of the palpebral conjunctiva.

Cicatricial trachoma is the end result of scarring that occurs in individuals who suffer from severe, persistent infections in childhood. Trachomatous scarring is recognized by the presence of easily visible white bands on the underside of the upper eyelid. Severe scarring can result in contraction of the tarsal conjunctiva which causes the lid margin to roll inwards. This results in buckling of the lid so the lashes rub on the eye known as trachomatous trichiasis. These lashes can lead to corneal opacities and scarring and eventually blindness.

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

  • Stage 1: Incipient - Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.
  • Stage 2: Established - Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.
  • Stage 3: Cicatrising - Scarring along with active infection.
  • Stage 4: Healed - Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

The image below shows trachomatous trichiasis with severe scarring-

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text: What is the drug of choice under the SAFE strategy for trachoma management?
questions.solution:
Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in the SAFE strategy of trachoma management. The adult dose is 1 g while 20 mg/kg body weight is given for children.

Oral azithromycin is slowly replacing tetracycline eye ointment as the first line drug used in trachoma treatment. The experience of Morocco, the first country that used azithromycin in a large-scale, nationwide elimination programme, has paved the way for the worldwide application of azithromycin as part of the SAFE strategy. 

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presented with the following lesion in his eye. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Bitot's spot, a pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia. Hence, the likely diagnosis in this 21-year-old man presenting with the above lesion is xerophthalmia.

Bitot's spot is a triangular, silvery-white, foamy patch on the bulbar conjunctiva which is usually bilateral. The most common site is temporal.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 10 year old malnourished boy is brought with a 2-month history of diminished night vision. His dietary history revealed a restricted diet, consisting of mainly chips and nuggets, and he would refuse to eat green leafy vegetables. What is the conjunctival change seen in this deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates that this patient has nyctalopia (diminished night vision) most likely due to vitamin A deficiency, suggested by his poor consumption of vegetables. Changes seen in the conjunctiva in vitamin A deficiency is hyperkeratosis of the squamous epithelium.

This occurs due to the metaplasia of the non-keratinized epithelium to keratinized epithelium. 

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology

X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation

X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ophthalmia nodosa occurs due to irritation due to caterpillar hair.

It is often mistaken for tuberculosis. On examination, small, semitranslucent, reddish and yellowish-grey nodules are formed in the conjunctiva, cornea, and iris. Microscopy contains caterpillar hair surrounded by giant cells and lymphocytes. Treatment includes excision of the nodules in the conjunctiva.   

The image below shows a patient's eye infected with ophthalmia nodosa.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with redness and photophobia of the left eye was seen in the OPD. An image of a characteristic lesion of her eye is as shown below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a white-pinkish nodule surrounded by hyperemia on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus with associated symptoms of redness and photophobia most likely has phlyctenular conjunctivitis. The given finding is referred to as a phlycten.

 Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Phlycten that may eventually form ring ulcers
  • Shallow marginal ulcer due to the breakdown of limbal phlycten known as scrofulous ulcer
  • Fascicular ulcer with a prominent parallel leash of blood vessels that heals leaving a band-shaped opacity

Treatment: Topical steroids; atropine if the cornea is involved.

Note: This can be differentiated from pinguecula by the following points:

Pinguecula is a yellow triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually remains free from conjunctival congestion.  The following image shows a yellow patch with tortuous blood vessels. There is no congestion as seen with a phlycten.

questions.text: Which of the following should not be considered in the differential of a patient who presents with the following finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows symblepharon, which is not seen in phlyctenular conjunctivitis. It is a partial or complete adhesion of the palpebral conjunctiva of the eyelid to the bulbar conjunctiva of the eyeball.

Causes of symblepharon:

  1. Chemical injuries (especially alkalis)
  2. Burns
  3. Ocular cicatrical pemphigoid (OCP)
  4. Steven–Johnson syndrome
  5. Erythema multiforme
  6. Pemphigus bullosa
  7. Membranous conjunctivitis

Management:

  • Lubrication
  • Sweeping of fornices
  • Symblepharon ring
  • Symblepharon release and amniotic membrane graft

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia is at present the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatarum in developed countries.

Ophthalmia neonatarum also called neonatal conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva occurring in an infant <30 days after birth.It should be ruled out in any infant having discharge or watering within the first week of birth.

Causes include:

  1. Chlamydia(Option A): neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by serotypes D-K is at present the most common cause in developed countries. 
  2. Gonorrhoea(Option B): effective prophylaxis against gonococcal infection and its subsequent decline has almost eliminated it's incidence in developed countries.
  3. Staphylococcus aureus(Option D), Haemophilus species, Streptococcus haemolyticus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae are other less commonly seen causes of ophthalmia neonatarum
  4. Herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatrum rarely occurs and is caused by Herpes simplex type 2 virus from the mother.
  5. Chemical conjunctivitis(Option C) is caused by the application of prophylactic antibiotics or silver nitrate at the time of birth. 
Time of presentation Causative agent
Within 48 h Chemical, Gonorrhoea
48–72 h

Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae
5–7 days Herpes simplex II
>1 week Chlamydia


Prophylactic treatment: 1% tetracycline or erythromycin eye ointment is applied to the eyes, if the mother is suspected to have gonococcal or chlamydia infection.

Curative treatment: 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis (D– K)- Erythromycin eye ointment
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae- Ceftriaxone injection, gentamicin drops, bacitracin eye ointment

The below image shows an infant presenting with ophthalmia neonatarum.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy had to miss school because the matting of his eyelids made it difficult to open them in the morning and caused severe pain. His agonized mother rushed him to the hospital and reported that he had a fever and red eye for 4 days. Which group of lymph nodes is likely to be enlarged?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever and red eyes, associated with matting of eyelids and pain, is suggestive of conjunctivitis. Lymph from the conjunctiva drains directly into the submandibular and preauricular nodes and hence, these group of lymph nodes are likely to be enlarged.

The lymphatic drainage of the conjunctiva is as follows-

  • From the medial side, one-third of the superior and medial two-thirds of the inferior conjunctiva → Submandibular nodes
  • From the lateral side, two-thirds of the superior conjunctiva and lateral one-third of the inferior conjunctiva → Preauricular nodes

Specialized collections of T and B lymphocytes underlying a modified epithelium is known as conjunctiva-associated lymphoid tissue (CALT) present in the stroma (substantia propria). It is critical in the initiation and regulation of ocular-surface immune responses. 

 Note:

The stroma also consists of the accessory lacrimal glands of Krause and Wolfring which are exocrine glands responsible for the basal secretion of the middle aqueous layer of the tear film.

questions.text: The image of the eye of a 32-year-old woman having superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis is given below. Which of the following is commonly associated with it?
questions.solution:
Superior limbic keratoconjunctivitis has a definite association with thyroid dysfunction. It affects one or both eyes of middle-aged women and about 65% of patients have abnormal thyroid function (usually hyperthyroidism).

It is a chronic disease of the superior limbus and the superior bulbar and the tarsal conjunctiva.

Clinical features:

  • Papillary hypertrophy of the superior tarsal plate, often having a diffuse velvety appearance.
  • Hyperemia of a radial band of the superior bulbar conjunctiva that stains with rose bengal.
  • Superior filamentary keratitis that develops in about one-third of cases.

Management:

  • Preservative-free lubricants
  • Topical acetylcysteine 10% to 20%, four times daily to break down filaments
  • Topical rebamipide

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not characteristic of pterygium?

choices.text: Abnormal activity of p53 is seen in the pterygium tissue.
Decreased activity of tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases is seen.
Destruction of Bowman's layer occurs when the pterygium invades the cornea.
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the connective tissue of the conjunctiva occur.

questions.solution:
Elastotic degeneration and hyalinization of the conjunctival connective tissue occurs in pinguecula (and not pterygium). 

In pterygium, there is elastotic degeneration of collagen with fibrovascular proliferation.

It is important to distinguish a pterygium from a pinguecula. A pterygium, while histologically similar to a pinguecula, is distinguished by fibrovascular tissue that grows onto the cornea. Pingueculae do not have vascularized tissue and do not cross the limbus.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

Vernal conjunctivitis is also called spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis. It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years. It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of the conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC - Cobblestone papillae are present in the upper tarsal conjunctiva associated with ropy discharge. Maxwell–Lyon sign is present which is a pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC - Horner – Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

The image given below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

Treatment of this condition is with topical steroids and mast cell stabilizers such as cromolyn sodium. Topical cyclosporine can be used in patients who do not respond to first line treatment modalities.

questions.text: Your professor has assigned you to proofread a seminar on the anatomy of the conjunctiva made by a junior. In the explanation of conjunctival follicles, you spot a wrong statement that needs revision. What is that statement?

choices.text: Conjunctiva of new born does not produce follicles before 2-3 months of age.
Slit lamp may be necessary to differentiate between follicles and papillae.
Follicles are a hyperplasia of the normal vascular system.
Follicles are found in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva.

questions.solution:
Papillae (not follicles) are hyperplasia of the normal vascular system, with glomerulus-like branches of capillaries growing into the epithelium in inflammatory conditions. On the other hand, follicles are yellowish-white, round elevations of 1-2 mm diameter. Follicles are a localized aggregation of lymphocytes present in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer of the conjunctiva.

Image: Conjunctival papillae (hyperplastic epithelium and capillaries) shown in the first image followed by conjunctival giant follicles (round yellowish-white elevations)  shown in the second image.

questions.text: In the grading of trachoma, the follicular stage is defined by the presence of which of the following?

choices.text: 5 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva
3 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
3 or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva

questions.solution:
In the grading of trachoma, follicular stage is defined by the presence of 5 or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva.

Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness worldwide. It is caused by an obligate intracellular bacterium called Chlamydia trachomatis Serotypes A–C. The infection is transmitted by direct or indirect transfer of eye and nose discharges of infected people, particularly young children who harbour the principal reservoir of infection.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin
